Sentence: Building a poor man’s home media network for less than $1,000.
Pulling It All Together
Quiznos, the sandwich shop chain, named Gregory D. Brenneman, a turnaround expert who is credited with revitalizing Burger King and Continental Airlines, president and chief executive on Monday.
Mr. Brenneman’s private equity firm, TurnWorks, has also taken an equity stake in Quiznos, the company said, although it did not disclose financial details.
Turnaround Expert Is Named Quiznos Chief
CBS is sitting on about $3 billion in cash, and with the hiring last November of new-media dealmeister Quincy Smith, everybody has been wondering what the company has in store.

CBS Chief Executive Leslie Moonves offered little in the way of hints either during his keynote address Tuesday at the Consumer Electronics Show or in a backstage interview with paidContent’s Staci D. Kramer.
Moonves Speaks, But Offers Few Hints on M&A
Fannie Mae’s former chief executive is seeking to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him.
Curb Sought on Fannie Mae Regulator

Fannie Mae’s former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court Wednesday to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him.

James B. Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, “has prejudged the charges” against him “and cannot serve as the impartial decision maker that due process requires,” Mr. Raines said in a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

On Dec. 18, the agency sued Mr. Raines; a former chief financial officer, J. Timothy Howard; and Fannie Mae’s former controller, Leanne G. Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.
Raines Seeks Curb on Fannie Mae Regulator

An article last Sunday about Martek Biosciences misidentified the headquarters city of D. A. Davidson & Company, which employs Timothy S. Ramey, a food and beverage analyst who now has an “underperform” recommendation on Martek’s stock.
Although Mr. Ramey’s office is in Portland, Ore., D. A. Davidson is based in Great Falls, Mont.
Correction
A partnership between Usmagazine.com and Veoh.com will create a celebrity entertainment channel on Veoh.
An Internet Video Partnership From 2 Lions of Old Media (Eisner and Jann Wenner)

The chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd, told Congressional lawmakers that his sale of company shares on Aug. 25 was “totally unrelated” to the fact that he was questioned the same day about an ill-fated internal investigation.

The sale of 100,000 shares of Hewlett-Packard was made during a scheduled window for trading by executives, Mr. Hurd wrote in a letter dated Dec. 21 that he sent to the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat.
On the same day the trade was completed, Mr. Hurd was interviewed by lawyers from the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati.
The lawyers were looking into techniques used by Hewlett-Packard to identify the source of boardroom leaks.
H.P.
Chief Defends Timing of Stock Sale
Bank of America had argued that the law restricting a bank to no more than 10 percent of the nation’s deposits is “antiquated” and anticompetitive.
Big Bank Stops Effort to Change Law Limiting Growth

Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions.

Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to “back off” from those plans.
Bank of America Tones Down Deposit Cap Stance
Dell's ATG D620 laptop includes a spill-resistant keyboard, heavy-duty case and 14-inch screen, which is visible in direct sunlight.
A Laptop Designed to Take a Licking and Keep on Ticking
Robert D. Novak, the writer who first named a C.I.A.
spy, has remained on the sidelines of a game he started.
Skipping Merrily Along as Others Take the Heat
Credit Suisse said Monday that it hired Michael D. Ryan, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs, as head of securities for its investment banking division.
Mr. Ryan will join Credit Suisse’s New York office some time “midyear,” Credit Suisse said.
He will oversee Credit Suisse’s global securities businesses and serve on the management committee of its investment banking group.
At Goldman Sachs, Mr. Ryan had been co-head of global equities.
Revolving Door: Credit Suisse, C.E.
Unterberg
The asset manager Janus Capital Group said Monday that its chief financial officer, Dave R. Martin, and general counsel, John H. Bluher, were leaving the firm in unrelated departures.
Three months ago, the chief executive, Gary D. Black, stepped down as chief investment officer in favor of two co-chief investment officers to focus on growing the business.
Two Executives to Leave Janus Capital
Reactrix, which makes interactive advertising displays projected on shopping mall floors, said it closed a $45 million Series D funding round, led by D.E.
Shaw Group and Menlo Ventures, both new investors.
The funding will go toward expanding its network of malls and theaters and developing new technology, the company said.
VC’s Light Up Reactrix With $45 Million
New York City’s first substantial campus for the life sciences will break ground between East 28th and 29th Streets and First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
Bringing Laboratory Space Back to New York
For the two activist hedge funds who had long called for a sale of Topps, Tuesday’s announcement that the baseball card maker would sell itself was hardly cause for celebration.

Topps director Arnaud Ajdler of Crescendo Partners — one of the two funds that eventually won representation on the Topps board — quickly came out against the proposed $385 million sale to Tornante, Michael D. Eisner’s investment firm, and Madison Dearborn Partners, a Chicago-based buyout firm.
For Activist Investors, Topps Sale Is Not Sweet Deal
The Canon D50 records to a mini-DVD but uses a 5.39-megapixel picture sensor to improve the picture quality.
A Palm-Size DVD Camcorder and a Handful of Ambition
David D. French, chief executive of the chip maker Cirrus Logic, has resigned over his involvement in the company’s past stock option grant practices, the company said on Wednesday.
Michael L. Hackworth, the former chief executive and current chairman, will be acting chief of the company he helped found, Cirrus said in announcing the results of an internal inquiry.
Cirrus Logic Chief Resigns Over Options

Two former executives at the computer maker Gateway were found liable on civil claims that they manipulated financial results to meet Wall Street expectations in 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday.

The verdicts against Gateway’s former chief financial officer, John J. Todd, and the former controller, Robert D. Manza, were announced by a federal jury in San Diego after a three-week trial, the S.E.C.
said.
Ex-Gateway Officers Found Liable in Trial

While hedge funds confidently flex their muscles in the markets and in boardrooms, in Washington they are experiencing the awkward growing pains of a relatively new industry coming to grips with its own power.
Some hedge funds like D. E. Shaw and Cerberus Capital Management have spent time and money in the capital, but most funds have been content to hope Washington will not rear its regulatory head.
In Lobbying Dance, Hedge Funds Are Still Learning the Steps
While investment banks are scrambling to get into the hedge fund business, officials say they need to know more about the industry.
House Panel Ponders the Growth and Risk of Hedge Funds

In a strange coincidence, Lehman Brothers‘ announcement that it had bought a 20 percent stake in D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund that is among the largest and oldest funds in the business, came the same day that the House Financial Services Committee held a hearing on hedge funds.
House Panel Ponders Risk of Hedge Funds

d Salzgitter, a German steel company, has dropped out of talks to buy a Canadian rival, Algoma Steel, after word of the secret negotiations leaked, driving up the price of a takeover and piquing the interest of other potential suitors.

While Salzgitter has walked away four weeks after starting talks, there are other “interested parties” that surfaced after news of the Salzgitter discussions became public last month, Algoma said Tuesday, adding that it plans to enter into negotiations with them in hopes of salvaging a sale.
Algoma Loses One Suitor, but Sees Others on the Horizon
Update: Kenneth D. Moelis will resign from UBS, DealBook reported Monday.
Go here for the latest item.
Another Departure in Store at UBS?
Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS’s investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, according to people briefed on the matter.
Future of UBS Executive Part of Wall Street Chatter
As reports surface that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS‘s investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, speculation on the whys and wherefores of the situation is increasing.
TXU, EchoStar Deals May Have Role in UBS Turmoil
The president of UBS’s investment bank who helped turn the Swiss bank into a mergers and acquisitions giant, is said to be leaving the firm.
Prominent UBS Executive to Leave

After an avalanche of reports surfaced that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS‘s investment bank, was considering ditching the firm following a series of run-ins with the Swiss bank’s management over private equity deals, The New York Times reports that Mr. Moelis, who helped turn the Swiss bank into a mergers and acquisitions giant, is indeed leaving.
UBS to Lose President of Investment Bank
It’s official: Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS‘ investment bank, is leaving.

DealBook obtained a copy of an internal memo by Huw Jenkins, the chairman and chief executive of UBS’ investment bank, and Peter A. Wuffli, the president of the firm’s Group Executive Board, announcing the veteran investment banker’s departure.
Moelis Is Leaving UBS: The Memo
The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday.

Mr. Lewis, 59, received $1.5 million in salary, $6.5 million in nonequity incentive plan compensation, and stock and option awards that were valued by the company at $14.6 million on the dates they were issued.
At Bank of America, $23 Million for Chief
Even with a big gun pointed at the newspaper business, most of the weapons at The Los Angeles Times seemed to be pointed inside.
The Circular Firing Squad in California

ECONOMIC DATA The Commerce Department will release revised figures for fourth-quarter gross domestic product (Thursday), which are expected to confirm a 2.2 percent annualized growth rate for the quarter.
The department will also release data on durable goods orders for February (Wednesday).
Economists forecast a 3.5 percent increase in orders for durable goods for the month, after an 8.7 percent decline in January.
The Labor Department will release its latest weekly reading of unemployment claims (Thursday).
The Week Ahead
Biomet, an orthopedics maker, said in a regulatory filing that Daniel P. Hann and Gregory D. Hartman knew or should have known of the backdating and the potential “ramifications.”
Another Biomet Executive Resigns After Stock Options Backdating Inquiry
Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed to buy casinos in Canada for $1.2 billion.
Australian Group Buys Canadian Casinos
Australia’s biggest gaming company, Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed Wednesday to buy casinos in Canada for 1.37 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion).
Mr. Packer joined with the Macquarie Bank to buy Gateway Casinos Income Fund, a casino operator in western Canada, for 886 million Canadian dollars, Publishing & Broadcasting said.
The venture also offered to buy two closely held casino management companies.
Australian Group Buys Canadian Casinos
Closing a $52 million Series D round of financing, Boston’s Surface Logix has raised $20 million to help fund clinical development of its small molecule drug candidates.
The round was fed by existing investors such as Venrock Associates, Arch Venture Partners, CW Group, HBM BioVentures, and Unilever Technology Partners.
Surface Logix Gets $20 Million in Series D Round
The planned sale would contradict earlier reports that Apollo Management was planning an initial public offering.
Equity Firm Is Seen Ready to Sell a Stake to Investors
Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black.
The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said.
DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.
Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
While new disclosure rules have resulted in far more information, analysts say they still do not necessarily offer greater insight into executive compensation.
More Pieces.
Still a Puzzle.

A second corporate advisory firm is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company’s annual meeting this month, underscoring the mounting investor discontent over the dual-class share structure of the Times Company and some of the strategic decisions taken by management.
Pressure Mounts on Times Co. as 2d Proxy Firm Enters Debate
A WiMax equipment startup, Telsima, announced a new $50 million Series D round of venture funding that will bankroll the company’s expansion plans in India and Eastern Europe.

Telsima, which makes WiMax-based broadband wireless access technology, received the money from its initial investor syndicate, which includes NewPath Ventures, New Enterprise Associates, CMEA Ventures, and Intel Capital.
WiMax Start-Up Picks Up $50 Million from V.C.’s

EARNINGS REPORTS The following companies are scheduled to release earnings reports this week: Citigroup, Eli Lilly, Mattel and Wachovia (Monday); TD Ameritrade Holding, Comerica, CSX, Dow Jones, EMC, Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Mellon Financial, Northern Trust, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Commerce Bancorp, E*Trade Financial, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Motorola, PNC Financial Services, Allstate, Bank of New York, Tribune and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Altria Group, Continental Airlines, D. R. Horton, First Data, Gannett, Google, Merck, Merrill Lynch, Nokia, Schering-Plough, Southwest Airlines, UnitedHealth Group and Wyeth (Thursday); Caterpillar, Honeywell, McDonald’s, SAP, Schlumberger and Xerox (Friday).
Looking Ahead

Some board members and shareholders of Topps, the baseball card maker, are furious with the company after it shunned a higher bid from its rival Upper Deck in favor of a $385 million deal with Disney’s former boss Michael D. Eisner, The New York Post reported.
Rival Offer Reignites Topps Battle
The board put off until next week a decision that could force Paul D. Wolfowitz  to resign as president of the bank.
World Bank Board to Decide Wolfowitz’s Fate

Diabetes drug developer Metabolex parlayed a strong partnership with Johnson & Johnson and promising early clinical data on its lead compound into a $32 million Series D round of venture capital from crossover investors, which could position the company for a public offering as soon as next year.
Metabolex Pumps V.C.s for $32 Million

Apple‘s former chief financial officer, Fred D. Anderson, is preparing to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the dating of an option grant to senior officials in January 2001, The New York Times reported Tuesday.
Apple’s Ex-C.F.O.
Reaches for Settlement with S.E.C.
A former Apple board member kept suspicions about Apple’s options-backdating policies swirling around Steven P. Jobs.
In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive

When the former chief financial oficer of Apple, Fred D. Anderson, suggested that he had been misled by his former boss, Steven P. Jobs, over the improper back-dating of options, the shot echoed through Silicon Valley.
In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive
Bruce D. Hertzke, chairman and chief executive of Winnebago Industries, spoke about high gas prices and about how some people save the fancy trimmings for their R.V.
instead of their house.
Rolling Homes Aren’t Just for the Rich

The optical implant developer ReVision Optics raised $25 million in a Series D financing led by Domain Associates to support clinical trials in its quest to deliver the first commercial implants to replace reading glasses in an aging population.
ReVision Sees $25 Million in New Round
D.E.
Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, announced Wednesday that it had hired Michael Joseph, a former banker at Lloyds TSB, to head its fledgling European private equity unit, D. E. Shaw Direct Capital.
Mr. Joseph, a former managing director of structured finance at Lloyds TSB, also served as an investment director at the British buyout shop 3i Group.
D.E.
Shaw Appoints European Private Equity Head
Those seeking a lesson in how to shake people up for money may want to take a page from the playbook of Hilary M. Weston.
Not All Donations Are Created Equal
Bank officials said that the special committee was still working on a punishment recommendation.
World Bank Panel Finds Wolfowitz at Fault; Aide Resigns
Alfred D. Chandler Jr. argued in almost two dozen books that the emergence of professional management propelled modern capitalism.
Alfred D. Chandler Jr., a Business Historian, Dies at 88
Acxiom, a data-management company, is being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private, the chief executive of Acxiom, Charles D. Morgan, announced Wednesday.
In a deal worth $2.25 billion, a partnership being formed by the equity firms ValueAct Capital and Silver Lake Partners will pay $27.10 a share in cash, Mr. Morgan said.
ValueAct Prevails Over Acxiom
The World Bank, the I.M.F.
and the W.T.O.
are now facing questions about their relevance in a global economy.
3 Global Financial Institutions’ Roles Questioned
The Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading.
Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the bank said.
Record mutual fund sales and rising demand for loans contributed to a 24 percent increase in consumer banking profit, countering the commodities losses, which were related to natural gas trading.
The bank said on May 17 that it would report a pretax trading loss of 680 million Canadian dollars.
Bank of Montreal said profit was 1.31 Canadian dollars a share excluding the trading loss and other one-time items, an increase of 3.1 percent from a year ago.
Revenue in the quarter, which ended April 30, rose 2.7 percent, to 2.57 billion Canadian dollars from 2.5 billion Canadian dollars.
Canada: Profit Up at Bank
VeriSign, which manages the dot-com and dot-net domain names registry, said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Stratton D. Sclavos, had resigned for undisclosed reasons.
Analysts were startled by the abrupt departure.
The company gave little information about the reason for Mr. Sclavos’s departure after 12 years as chief executive.
VeriSign’s Chief Executive Resigns Abruptly
Look at the shares of the nation’s 10th-largest seller of residential housing and you might think that the real estate bubble never popped.
Who Benefits From This Buyback?
The president of the Condé Nast Media Group has developed an agencylike business within the ad sales unit.
Publishers Creating Their Own In-House Ad Agencies
Some economists say that while Jeffrey Sachs means well, he is peddling a dream that will always be just that: a dream.
Can a Vision Save All of Africa?

Topps said Monday that it would postpone a vote on a $385 million buyout offer by two private equity firms, including one run by Michael D. Eisner, after a Delaware chancery court judge ruled that the baseball card maker must disclose more information about the deal.
Topps said it would also allow a rival, Upper Deck, to make a tender offer to its shareholders, in accordance with the decision by Judge Leo Strine Jr.
Topps to Postpone Vote on Private Equity Buyout
Kenneth Rice, who turned government witness and testified in the trial of former Enron C.E.O.
Jeffrey Skilling and company founder Kenneth Lay, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison.
Ex-Enron Executive Sentenced to Prison
A solar cell and module maker Advent Solar, said on Tuesday it had secured more than $70 million in a series D funding to ramp up production at its four-month old production facility.
V.C.’s Shower Advent Solar With Cash
Robert B. Zoellick, the new chief of the World Bank, will need to smooth ruffled feathers left by his predecessor Paul D. Wolfowitz.
Mending Fences at World Bank

The E. D. Smith Income Fund, a trust that owns a variety of private-label food manufacturing operations, said it planned to sell all of its assets to TreeHouse Foods of the United States in a deal valued at about C$217 million ($203 million).
Treehouse Buys Private Food Manufacturer
In a Series D funding, Paracor Medical raised $44.35 million to complete a pivotal clinical trial of a device to prevent congestive heart failure, says TheDeal.com.
Paracor Raises $44 Million for Pivotal Trial
The tiny island nation of São Tomé may have attracted oil-related corruption without producing any oil.
No Oil Yet, but African Isle Finds Slippery Dealings
TuneCore, a digital music distributor, is expected to announce that Public Enemy, one of the seminal hip-hop groups, will use its service for its new album.
Public Enemy to Use a Digital Distributor
With Americans seemingly developing a taste for news with a Fleet Street twist, British papers are stepping up their efforts to court American readers and advertisers.
British News Sites Seek Out Readers in the U.S.
Emergent Game Technologies has secured $12 million in series D funding, The Triangle Business Journal reported Tuesday.
The company makes video-game technology and will use the new cash to consolidate its northern California office into its existing research and development facility in Chapel Hill, N.C.
Emergent Game Technologies Scores $12 Million
Richard D. Fairbank, the chairman of Capital One Financial, keeps his eye on the “Gretzky Concept” as he moves into retail banking.
Chief of Capital One Applies Hockey Strategies to Banking
Allen & Company’s annual summit, being held this week in Sun Valley, Idaho, brings together some of media and entertainment’s biggest moguls.
Business Casual
Since May, the chairman and chief executive of Capital One Financial has exercised more than 10,000 options every day, collecting as much as $3.4 million each week.
What’s in His Wallet?
Millions in Options
At Allen & Company’s rarefied annual summit for media moguls, the titans arrived, the guest list shimmered, but the deals didn’t happen.
High Wattage at Sun Valley, but No Deals

Writing about his trip to Allen & Company‘s mogul-packed media conference last week, The New York Times’ David Carr said “the only transaction I saw consummated was Richard D. Parsons selling a chair on the patio bar for 45 cents to Michael S. Ovitz.”
Will Richard Parsons Sell More than a Barstool?
Satiety has brought in $30 million in Series D funding to support the first United States clinical trials of a new medical device to control obesity.
The six-year-old startup now has more than $50 million in investments.
Investors Serve Up $30 Million for Satiety
Michael D. Capellas is emblematic of a new breed of mercenary manager who perform quick resuscitations on floundering companies before moving on to the next job.
Job-Hopping, or, Hello, He Must Be Going
Time was when serial job-hopping was a stain on a corporate résumé.
Michael D. Capellas has turned it into a career.
Private Equity’s Paratrooper C.E.O.
Richard D. Fain, chief of Royal Caribbean Cruises, says that today’s cruise lines are going after a younger and more active clientèle.
Casting Off the Myths of Cruises
HOUSING INDICATORS The housing sector will take center stage with earnings reports from three big homebuilders, Pulte Homes (Wednesday) and Beazer and D. R. Horton (Thursday).
There will also be reports on existing home sales for June (Wednesday) and new-home sales for June (Thursday).
Looking Ahead
Veoh, the online video company backed by Time Warner and Michael D. Eisner among others, said on Wednesday that it had hired a former advertising executive at Yahoo as its new chief executive.
The new chief, Steve Mitgang, will succeed the founder, Dmitry Shapiro, who will become chief innovation officer.
Veoh Hires Ex-Yahoo Ad Executive as New C.E.O.
Five people were named to a committee intended to protect the editorial independence of the Wall Street Journal when it becomes part of News Corporation.
Murdoch and Dow Jones Pick 5 to Safeguard Wall St. Journal
After a meeting of the top 50 executives of Bear Stearns, the group has embraced Alan D. Schwartz as the firm’s sole president and likely successor to the chief executive James E. Cayne.
Bear Stearns Heir Apparent Tries to Restore Some Faith
TIP OF THE WEEK: If you spend a lot of time looking up locations around the United States on map sites, the Map+ add-on for the Firefox browser can save time.

Once you install Map+ (available at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/2394), you can highlight an address on a Web page and right-click on it to see a small Yahoo map of the location pop up in the Firefox window.
J. D. BIERSDORFER
Tip of the Week: Speed Your Online Mapping
NBC said it was ready to stop showing reruns of the episodes former Senator Fred D. Thompson appears in because of federal equal time regulations for presidential candidates.
If Thompson Runs for President, Don’t Look for Him in Reruns
Many Medtronic shareholders may be happy to see Arthur D. Collins Jr. step down as chief executive.
Inheriting Some Frustrations at Medical Device Maker
Despite a tough ride as Time Warner C.E.O., Richard D. Parsons prefers that you never see him busting his chops.
Running an Empire?
No Sweat
LOOKING TO THE FED While the markets have stabilized a bit, investors still wonder whether the Federal Reserve will cut the federal funds rate.

They will be scrutinizing any remarks made on Friday by the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, at the annual symposium of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., in Jackson Hole, Wyo., which continues Saturday.
Looking Ahead

The Topps Company has postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $384.5 million buyout from a group led by Michael D. Eisner, the former Walt Disney Company chief executive, giving investors more time to consider the offer.
Topps Delays Vote on Buyout Offer
The goal is for the school, if approved by the Department of Education, to open to an estimated 400 students in September 2008.
Brooklyn Could Get a High School for Marketers
Update: First Data has officially closed its $26 billion buyout by K.K.R.
Michael D. Capellas, the former chief executive of Compaq, will replace Henry Duques as chairman and C.E.O., among other personnel changes.First Data appears to be right on time.
First Data Closes $26 Billion Buyout
Even in the luxury segment, noise is an issue at hotels, especially as older ones undergo renovations.
Noises Off, Please

Just days after Nordic investment bank D. Carnegie lost its board and chief executive as a result of trading irregularities, two of its competitors have emerged as its largest owners, triggering takeover speculations.
Nordic Investment Bank’s Woes Spark Deal Chatter
Many investors have grown increasingly impatient with the company’s less-than-stellar performance, according to people with knowledge of the search.
Sprint Nextel Is Said to Seek a New Chief
Gary D. Forsee’s resignation came on the heels of news reports last week that the company’s board was seeking to replace him as early as December.
Sprint Nextel Chief Resigns, Adding to Line of Departures
Is Gary D. Forsee’s departure from Sprint another feather in Ralph V. Whitworth’s cap?
What Did Whitworth Do at Sprint?

Internet advertising start-up ReachLocal has closed a $55.2 million Series D venture financing to offer small local businesses the same services that aQuantive and ValueClick provide to Fortune 500 companies.
ReachLocal Nabs $55 Million
James D. Farley is the third high-ranking official to leave Toyota for one of the struggling Detroit automakers in recent months.
Ford Names a Toyota Executive as Marketing Chief
After a summer of bad news, home builders are now cheap enough for some investment advisers to recommend buying.
Anticipating the Upside in Housing
If you are taking one last look at a document in Microsoft Word’s Print Preview mode and notice a typo, you do not have to leave the Print Preview screen to fix it.
Tip of the Week: Making Edits in Print Preview
An increasingly vocal and potent anti-coal movement in the West includes ranchers, farmers and religious groups.
Fight Against Coal Plants Draws Diverse Partners
The plans to cut 3,000 jobs followed a terrible third quarter in which the investment banking unit’s profit dropped 93 percent after virtually every area performed poorly.
Shake-Up and Job Cuts at Bank of America
“The Last Tycoons” is an insider’s history of Lazard Freres & Company, where William D. Cohan worked for six years as an investment banker.
Lazard History Wins Book Prize
A book written by William D. Cohan, a New York journalist who went to work on Wall Street, won the Financial Times and Goldman Sachs Business Book of the Year Award yesterday.
Lazard History Wins Industry Book Prize
Having emerged as a leading candidate to succeed E. Stanley O’Neal at Merrill Lynch, BlackRock founder Laurence D. Fink may be the king of Wall Street’s C.E.O.
short list.
A Perpetual Name on Wall Street’s Short Lists Is a Front-Runner at Merrill
E. Stanley O’Neal is expected to resign as early as Monday as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch.
Risk-Taker’s Reign at Merrill Ends With Swift Fall
Most Wall Street chief executives struggle to keep the job they have.
Laurence D. Fink, the founder of the BlackRock investment management firm, has the opposite problem.
His name constantly surfaces for new ones.
A Perpetual Shortlistee, Now Touted at Merrill
Whoever is chosen will have to run both a thriving wealth management operation and a beaten-down bond business.
A Search for a Chief Who Can Unite Merrill Lynch
Laurence D. Fink is being bandied about as one of the top candidates to succeed E. Stanley O’Neal as head of Merrill Lynch.

He would bring a strong track record as the leader of BlackRock, the asset management firm he founded in 1988 and merged with Merrill’s asset management arm in 2006, as well as blend of banking and trading acumen.
Merrill Lynch’s $32 Million Man?
The departures of two top black executives have started a debate over whether they helped to break down barriers.
Is There Room at the Top for Black Executives?
Standard & Poor’s cut the credit ratings of the three largest American home builders — Lennar, Pulte Homes and D. R. Horton — to junk yesterday as demand for new homes deteriorated.
Credit Ratings Cut to Junk for Top 3 Home Builders
Jeffrey L. Bewkes will succeed Richard D. Parsons as the chief executive on Jan. 1, the company announced today, confirming a widely expected transition of power.
Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner Chief
Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
If the Hollywood screenwriters go on strike, the typical American household will not run out of content any time soon.
But will the audience return after a lengthy strike?
New Media, New Value, Old Troubles
Laurence D. Fink may be closer to taking the reins at Merrill Lynch.
The securities firm’s board of directors has told Mr. Fink, the chairman of BlackRock, that the top spot is his should he want it, CNBC reported citing unnamed sources.
Merrill Is Said to Favor Fink as New C.E.O.
Richard D. Parsons is about to have a lot of time on his hands.
Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner C.E.O.
Next January
After months of speculation, Time Warner said that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year.
At Time Warner, Successor to Parsons Emerges
